RehresentatiUes Of tie United States Of H.
merica in Congress assembled, That the
Register and Receiver Of the Land Office at St.
Stephens b., and they are hereby authorized to
and directed to receive from the corporation of
the City of Mobile, the, sum of one. dollar and
twenty-five cenrs per acre, for aqusntity Of land
not exceeding four sections, at Aorsnear Spring
Hill, in the county of Mobile, anT State Of Ala
bama; and, upon receipt of said sum as aforesaid,
the said Register and Receiver shall issue their
certificate to, and in the name of the corporation
of the city of Mobile, for the said quantity Of
land, not exceeding four sections as aforesaid.


SEC. 2. Ind be it further enacted, That, for
and in consideration of, the sum aforesaid, paid
as aforesaid, that all the right and claim of the
United States, to the said quantity of land, not
exceeding four sections in the county of Mobile
and State aforesaid, be, and the same is hereby,
vested in the Mayor and Aldermen Of the said ci-
ty Of Mobile, for the time being, and their sue
cessors in office, to be applied disposed of by
them, for the sole use and benefit of the said CT
ty forever: Pror,ded, That no part of any claim,
arising from acts Of Congress, known as donations
or prescriptions by the reported list of actual
settlers, or from grants recognized by any Treaty
shall be covered or taken by this grant, but the
same shall be exempted from, and held as not
covered or interfered with by this act.


SEC 3. find be it further enacted, That pat
cnts shall issue, upon the presentation OF said
cert ficate of the Register and Receiver aforesaid
for he said quantity of land, not exceeding four
sections, to the corporation ofthe City of Mobile,
in the same manner that patents now issue upon
the final certificate for other public lands.


Approved: March, 8, 1927.

At Bowdoin College. i'll the State Of Maiae,
the students have lately shown themselves
somewhat refractory TO the discipline OF the
place. One Of their number was suspended
eight or ten days for some offence, aud his
class finding the sentence not 70 agree WIN
their views of the Justice Of the case, reSoiv-
ed to do something really worthy OF pnnish


ment The first demonstration OF a flatons
disposition was made by procuring barrel
of tar, to which they set fire III the hH5ht
near the college buildings, aud danced round
it yelling like sayages. After tins ccrcmo-
ny, which seems to have been intended as a
kind Of declaration of war, they proceeded
to actual hostilties. A quantity OF powder
was placed under the tutors chair with a
train leading to ii. and while he was hearing
their lessons, the train was set on fire and
the gentleman suddenly enveloped IN flame
and smoke. fled for his lte.-Soon after, the
chapel bell, which had so long ANNOYED these
young worthless by its mportunate summons
to prayers and recitatons, was taken down,
and it is supposed thrown into the river. =
variety CT other pranks We're PLAYED but VI
CLIENT inquiries being st on foot to discover
the ring leaders in these disturbances, three
of them have been sent away, and the re-
mainder are beginning to be satisfied.

The following singular notice appeared in
one Of the Baltimore daily papers, a few days
slnce:-


"qJ a person who pleaded in England, some
time apo, Tor the benefit of an ancient law,
since rcpealcd) in peculiar emergency, and
Who is row supposed to be in the United States
, under fictitious name, may receive letter from
, his mother, in such manner as he shall adopt
for concealng his person, on an iategiofe appll-
cation, postage being pad,) to II. Niles, edi-
tor of the ltegiscr,"
The notice excited much attention and
caused SO many inquiries to be made of the re-
spectacle editor Of the Register, that on Mon
day he came out with the following erplanton:


''iiaying inserted the preceding notice IN one
of the Baltimore daily papers, we shall satisfy the
enquiries which it has caused by saying, that
by a late arrival from Liverpool, We have receiv-
ed letter for "Abraham Thornton" who was
charged with rape and murder on the person OF
a beautiful Young woman named Mary Ashford
and avoided the penalty of the law by plead
i g the benefit of an old statute (not supposed
to be in exisence,) to prove his innocence in
the absence of positive testimony by "Wdger and
bQttle," with the nearest kin of the deceased;
and no one appearing to contend with him, he
was discharged. The letter is said to be from
his old and afflicted mother, and will be deliver

Washington's Revolutionary Papers have

ranped according to the following classltica-
ton.


l. Letters to the Congress OF the United


States-to committees Of Congress


TO the American Ministers Plenipo-


tentary at Foreign CotIts; to indi-


yidual Members Of Congress in their


public characters. Ihis class contains


seven vols.


}, Letters 10 officers ol the Line, OF every


rank; to officers Of the Stall; ana to


all other military Characters OF every


denomination. Sixteen vols.


Letters to Conventions and Committees


ut Safety and Correspondence, to Go-


vernors Presidents, and other exec


utives Of States. to Civil Magistrates,


and citizens of every denominaton.--


livc vols


T. Letters to Foreign Ministers; to sub


iects of foreign nations in the immc-


date service of the United States,


but not in virtue Of commissions from


Con3rcs to foreign officers OF all


descriptions. Two vols


5. Letters to officers of every rank and de-


denomination in the service ot the en-


cmy; 10 British subjects of every char


acter, with the enemy; to persons APP


plying for permission to go to the en-


emy One vol.


& Proceedings and opinions OF Councils OF


War, and opinions Of the general OF


fcers respecting the various points on


which they were consulted from time


to time, by the Conmandern-C Chief.


/ hree vols.


:. Private Correspondence during the


Revelation, being letters written TO


persons both III private and public sta.


tons, but on subjects OF private na-


turc. Three vols.


8. Orderly Books, containing all the or


ders to the Army, entered in detail


from the day he took command OF 1t


at Cambridge, till h. left It at New


burgh, at the end q the war. Seven


vols


These volumes are arranged WITH re-
markahle eXactness OF method, copied with
elegance and care. and written Throughout
in uniform and neat style OF penmahshiP,
Each class Of subjects is brought together
in strict Chronological order, and copion,
index is added 10 every volume.


From the time that Washington resigned

lis letters to Nfr. Jay, upon the subject Of

ord that breads the light, none that would

A most surprising and dreadful occurrence
lately took place in one Of the provinces D
France. A counterfeiter, who had beer
condemned to be hung, made his escape o,
the way to the gallows, and took refuge il
an hospital. After some search lie wa
found, as was thought, disguised. lie wa
Carried OF, uttcrlng not syllable, but ges
ticulating vehemently, and executed. 1t wa
shortly afterwards discovered that the off
GERS had hung deaf and dumb brother o
the convict who had resided long in the hos
pital. The real criminal vas recommends,
to the royal clemency.


Il Laughablc adrcntute-No long since
reverend clergyman in Vermont, being ap
prchonsive that the accumulated weight {
snow upon the roof Of his barn might d
some damage, resolved to prevent it bv sea
sonably slioyeling it off, He therefore as
oenued II, having first, for tear the sno,
might all slide otf at once, and himself wit
II, fastened to his waist one end of a rope
ana giving the other to his WIFE He wen
10 work, but fearing still tor his safety, IN
dear said he, ''tie the rope round you
waist" no sooner had she done this, than o
went the snow, poor minister and all, ant
up went his wife. Thus on one side of til
barn the astounded and confaunlcd clergy
man hung, but on the other side hung hi
vlte, high aud dry, i'll majesty sublime
dlngllng and dangling at the end of the rop,
~ that moment, however, gentleman
luckily passing by, delivered them from thei
perllous situation Per. Pat.

Boiipar as FaaHcier.-A letter lies be-
fore us written by an American at Porto Ca.
bello, Gated the 21th u't. which furnishes
the following intoi nation as to the Liberia
tors notion Of raising the ways and means
to meet the debt of the country, The ex-
tract is given literally.


stately Bolivar has laid an Alcavaila duty
on all produce, say s per cent on the vana-
tion, which is taken from tho current sales
He has also laid n tax of $500 on all mcr-
chants transacting commission businrss--on
Nil retail dry good stores one ol s150-and
OH smaller establishments, one OF from $50
to 500 per annum.


"Ihese taxes will produce revenue of
from to million dollars. lie has dis
charged all military officers of duty, giving
them preference in civil employment,
when they have capacity to fill them; he has
reduced the present pay one half-abolish-
ed the reception ofthe government paper for
season in the custom honses-and, IN fact,
has made such alterations as will in nine
months pay the interest il not part OF the
principal Of the national debt. More than
tqpo hundred : !! di&aNectcd fer$on$ hare
been shot IN Cumann and .dburc, and Gen.
Paez has carried all before him in executing
Bulivar's decrees. He is desperate and
strict to every order of the l.lherator"


The writer Of the above Is a plain, fair
man-and his statement is remarkable on
several acc counts.-Fiist, as communicating,
as we believe, the first intelligence OF the
very decisive steps Of bolivar in exciting
for SO il must be called-suppiies. Second
| ", shelving, by the natural reference to
4 Bolivar, aud to him alone, as the author Ct
4 an measures, that he is the only power in
Colombia thirdly, as justitying by the fact
Of the execution by two hundreds, OF the
disaffccted--a word Of large in,rort--the
caution to which we haze before referred,
Of cur correspondents Al I.sguayra. in with
holding their names from their letters


Altogether, the state Of Colombia IS lar
from satisfactory.

Mr. Zeumer, an industrious confectioner
OF Cincinnati, Ohio, was indisposed few
days last week; on Friday morning, beng
much better, he went to his shop at an early
hour, and drank freely from his cold soda
fountain. The immediate consequence was,
the rupture of a blood vessel, which caused
his death in few hours.

RehresentatiUes Of tie United States Of H.
merica in Congress assembled, That the
Register and Receiver Of the Land Office at St.
Stephens b., and they are hereby authorized to
and directed to receive from the corporation of
the City of Mobile, the, sum of one. dollar and
twenty-five cenrs per acre, for aqusntity Of land
not exceeding four sections, at Aorsnear Spring
Hill, in the county of Mobile, anT State Of Ala
bama; and, upon receipt of said sum as aforesaid,
the said Register and Receiver shall issue their
certificate to, and in the name of the corporation
of the city of Mobile, for the said quantity Of
land, not exceeding four sections as aforesaid.


SEC. 2. Ind be it further enacted, That, for
and in consideration of, the sum aforesaid, paid
as aforesaid, that all the right and claim of the
United States, to the said quantity of land, not
exceeding four sections in the county of Mobile
and State aforesaid, be, and the same is hereby,
vested in the Mayor and Aldermen Of the said ci-
ty Of Mobile, for the time being, and their sue
cessors in office, to be applied disposed of by
them, for the sole use and benefit of the said CT
ty forever: Pror,ded, That no part of any claim,
arising from acts Of Congress, known as donations
or prescriptions by the reported list of actual
settlers, or from grants recognized by any Treaty
shall be covered or taken by this grant, but the
same shall be exempted from, and held as not
covered or interfered with by this act.


SEC 3. find be it further enacted, That pat
cnts shall issue, upon the presentation OF said
cert ficate of the Register and Receiver aforesaid
for he said quantity of land, not exceeding four
sections, to the corporation ofthe City of Mobile,
in the same manner that patents now issue upon
the final certificate for other public lands.


Approved: March, 8, 1927.

full articles.article:
AN ACT concerning the location Of land rcscry-


ed for the use ofa Seminary Of Learning in the


State Of Louisiana.


Be il enacted by the Senate and House Ct
Representatives IF the UnHcd STATES of.4
merica in Congress assembled, That the
Secretary of the Treasury be, and he is hereby,
authorized to locate quantity Of llnd not ey-
ceedng two entire townships, reserved by the
eleventh section ofthe act oftwents first April,
eighteen hundred and six; and by tho seventh,
section of the act Of the third Of March, eighteen
hundred and eleven, for the use of 4 seminary Of
learning in the State Of Louisiana, on any Of the
public lands in said State, in sections CORES
ponling with any Of the legal divisions into
which the public lands are authorized to be sun
vcyed.


SIC. 9. md be it ji4rihsr enacted, That, 50
soon as the location Of said lands shall be made
aforesaid, the title thereto shall be, and is here
by, vested in the State Of Louisiana, for the use
Of seminary or semnaries Of learning therein, as
the Legislature of said State may direct.


Approved March 8, 1927.

y


Navy of the United States.


BE il enacted 6y the Senate and House Of
Representatives IF The U1,Aet States Of II
mertca in Congress assembled, That for
tile gradual improvement OF the Navy of the T.
nited States, the sum Of FIVE hundred thousand
dollars per annum, for six years, is also ap-
proproprated, to be applied as in this act pre-
scrbed, and as may, hereafter, be directed by
law.


SEC. 2. Ind be il further Enacted, That
the President of the Unit d States be, ard he is
hereby, authorized to cause to be procured,
ship timber suitable for the construction of YES
sells Of the various classes now recognised i'll the
Navy ofthe United States, and also the timber
proper for the construction OF steam batteries;
and to take the proper measures Tor having the
said timber duly seasoned and preserved, 50 as to
be I'll for immediate use.


SEC. 5. Ind be ii .farther enacted, That
the President Of the United States be, and he is
hereby, au iorizcd to take the proper measures
10 preserve the live OAK timber growing on the
lands Of the United States, and he is hereby au
thorized to reserve from s.le such lands, belong
ing to the inited states, as may he found to con-
tain live oak, or other timber, in sufficient guam
tity to render the same valuable for Naval pur-
poses


SEC 4, Ind be il .fArtder enacted, That
the President of the United States be, and he is
hereby, authorized to cause to be constructed,
two dry docks on the most approved plan, for the
use of the Navy of the United States, the one
of said docks to be erected at some point TO the
South, and the other to the North Of the Potomac
River.


1 SEC. S. Ind be il further enaeted, That
/ the President Of the United States be, and he is
hereby, authorized TO cause the necessary exam.
inations and inquiries to be made, o ascertain,
the practicabilitv and expcd ency of erecting a
Marine Railway for the repair Of sloops of war,
and other vessels Of All inferior class, at pensaco.
Ia, and if it shall appear from such inquiry an
[andj examination, that such Railway would be
useful to the Navy Of the United States, and can
be constructed at a reasonable expense, that he
cause the sane 10 be constructed on the most
approved plan.


SEC. 6. .4Qd Be n further enacted, That
The President of the United States be, and he is
hereby, authorized to cause tile Navy Yards OF
the United states to be thoroughly examined,
and plans to be prepared, and sanctioned BY the
President, for the improvement Of the same, and
the preservation Of the public property the ren
/, from which plans deviat OH shall hereafter be
made bat by his special ordr.
( SEC. Z. Ind BE- il Jurthef enactcd, That
the money appropriated br this act Shall not be
transferred to any other object OF expenditure,
nor shah any part thereof be carried TO tAe fund
cienominatvl the surplus fuGl, and annual re.
por.s shall BE submitted to Congress OF the x
pcnl;tures under this act and tic measures taken
to carry the same into effect.


Approvcd March 5, 1877

AN ACT to provide for the completion Of the


road from point opposite to Memphis. III the

Of Tennessee, to Little Rock, in the Territory of
Arkansas. 10 be paid, as the same may be requlr-
cd, out Of any money in the Treasury, not other
wise appropriated by lax.


SEC. ,. Ind BE il furthtr crGctc1, That
the President Of the United States be, and he is

opened from Fort Smith, on the Arkansas river,
to Fort Towson, on the Red riycr, and from

SEC. s. .qad be II Jinflcr eancted That the

priated


Approved March 3, 1897

full articles.headline: 4 Valuable Farm for Sale.
full articles.article:
9xszA ss offered 70 private sale, a Valua.
fp1.MsgsINIsA ID dle Farm, situated in Pencadcr
ssssssAeSASs 4 drcd, Newcastle County, Del. a.
e2ssssss.ssss laut mile south Of Newark; adjoin.
ing lilus OF +. Ii. ,,oltzkecker, the heirs of Will
liam Lindsey, dec, Zacffariah Jones, and others.
containing U6acrcs, ''nore or less. his Farm
is on black oak and hickory soil, in a high state
Of cultivation, and equaled by few in the neigh
bourhood;--it is well adapted to all kinds of
Grasses and Grain;--has Oh it a young thriving
orchard of about one hundred trees of choice
fruits an excellent bottom meadow, through
which runs never falling stream; and seven TIL
agcs or fields, all under good fence. The i'm
provements are two story log dwelling house,
well weathcr-boarded outside and lathed and
plastered inside, having three rooms down and
four up stairs, with first rate cellar under the
whplc.-Aso, kitchen adjoining, with pump
of excellent water at the door; a stone milk
house and smoke house; frame barn, nearly
new, with excellent stabling underneath suhi-
cient TO hold ten or twelve head of horses, be-
sides mich cows, calves, &c. Further descrip-
lion is deemed unnecessary, as it is expected
that any wishing to purchase will view the prem.
ises, which the subscriber, living thereon, can
show, and make known the conditions of sale


JOHN PITNER.


May 2s, 1927. S7-4t.

full articles.headline: EXECUTION.
full articles.article:
Joseph Soils, who was convicted at the
last term of the Superior Court of Dulpin
Co. IN. c. of the murder of Abraham kor-
negay, underwent the sentence OF the law
on Friday, the 9th ult From the want OF
proper caution in tying the rope, the feet OF
the criminal came to the grosnd and broke
the fall. He remained in this position part
" standing, groaning in the greatest appa,,


rent agony, for above seven minutes. Al
was now in confusion, the crowd murmuring
and nothing doing. The sheriff himself ap-

Feared completely unnamed, and incapable
OF making any exertion to put the unfortu-
nate man out of pain. At length gentle
nan present, took up piece of plank, push
cd back the rope and suspended him in this
position about fifteen minutes. A medical
gentleman present observed "hc was com
ing to life" On hearing this the sheriff had
him taken up and pitched off the scaffold
again, and ended his sufTer.rgs.

full articles.headline: COLLEGE TROLICS.
full articles.article:
At Bowdoin College. i'll the State Of Maiae,
the students have lately shown themselves
somewhat refractory TO the discipline OF the
place. One Of their number was suspended
eight or ten days for some offence, aud his
class finding the sentence not 70 agree WIN
their views of the Justice Of the case, reSoiv-
ed to do something really worthy OF pnnish


ment The first demonstration OF a flatons
disposition was made by procuring barrel
of tar, to which they set fire III the hH5ht
near the college buildings, aud danced round
it yelling like sayages. After tins ccrcmo-
ny, which seems to have been intended as a
kind Of declaration of war, they proceeded
to actual hostilties. A quantity OF powder
was placed under the tutors chair with a
train leading to ii. and while he was hearing
their lessons, the train was set on fire and
the gentleman suddenly enveloped IN flame
and smoke. fled for his lte.-Soon after, the
chapel bell, which had so long ANNOYED these
young worthless by its mportunate summons
to prayers and recitatons, was taken down,
and it is supposed thrown into the river. =
variety CT other pranks We're PLAYED but VI
CLIENT inquiries being st on foot to discover
the ring leaders in these disturbances, three
of them have been sent away, and the re-
mainder are beginning to be satisfied.

ING, (rhursday,) at O'Clock. Young men de-

The following singular notice appeared in
one Of the Baltimore daily papers, a few days
slnce:-


"qJ a person who pleaded in England, some
time apo, Tor the benefit of an ancient law,
since rcpealcd) in peculiar emergency, and
Who is row supposed to be in the United States
, under fictitious name, may receive letter from
, his mother, in such manner as he shall adopt
for concealng his person, on an iategiofe appll-
cation, postage being pad,) to II. Niles, edi-
tor of the ltegiscr,"
The notice excited much attention and
caused SO many inquiries to be made of the re-
spectacle editor Of the Register, that on Mon
day he came out with the following erplanton:


''iiaying inserted the preceding notice IN one
of the Baltimore daily papers, we shall satisfy the
enquiries which it has caused by saying, that
by a late arrival from Liverpool, We have receiv-
ed letter for "Abraham Thornton" who was
charged with rape and murder on the person OF
a beautiful Young woman named Mary Ashford
and avoided the penalty of the law by plead
i g the benefit of an old statute (not supposed
to be in exisence,) to prove his innocence in
the absence of positive testimony by "Wdger and
bQttle," with the nearest kin of the deceased;
and no one appearing to contend with him, he
was discharged. The letter is said to be from
his old and afflicted mother, and will be deliver


al

The Lexington (Ky.) Gazette states that
counterfeit $500 notes. Of the United States
nrahch Bank at Orleans, arc in circu-
auon They are lettered E to H, doubly
numbered, ~ filled in and endorsed Chas. $.
~, Mnest, Cashier--signed N Biddle, Prcs't.,

eas'e IS coarse and defective, and its left

alorders. as they were issued daily, from thc
lime he entered Virginia. until his defeat
syceptng few days in which Washington
VAS confined BY fever.


Washington's Revolutionary Papers have
III been transcribed into large folio volumes,
anounting to forty -four in number, and ar
ranped according to the following classltica-
ton.


l. Letters to the Congress OF the United


States-to committees Of Congress


TO the American Ministers Plenipo-


tentary at Foreign CotIts; to indi-


yidual Members Of Congress in their


public characters. Ihis class contains


seven vols.


}, Letters 10 officers ol the Line, OF every


rank; to officers Of the Stall; ana to


all other military Characters OF every


denomination. Sixteen vols.


Letters to Conventions and Committees


ut Safety and Correspondence, to Go-


vernors Presidents, and other exec


utives Of States. to Civil Magistrates,


and citizens of every denominaton.--


livc vols


T. Letters to Foreign Ministers; to sub


iects of foreign nations in the immc-


date service of the United States,


but not in virtue Of commissions from


Con3rcs to foreign officers OF all


descriptions. Two vols


5. Letters to officers of every rank and de-


denomination in the service ot the en-


cmy; 10 British subjects of every char


acter, with the enemy; to persons APP


plying for permission to go to the en-


emy One vol.


& Proceedings and opinions OF Councils OF


War, and opinions Of the general OF


fcers respecting the various points on


which they were consulted from time


to time, by the Conmandern-C Chief.


/ hree vols.


:. Private Correspondence during the


Revelation, being letters written TO


persons both III private and public sta.


tons, but on subjects OF private na-


turc. Three vols.


8. Orderly Books, containing all the or


ders to the Army, entered in detail


from the day he took command OF 1t


at Cambridge, till h. left It at New


burgh, at the end q the war. Seven


vols


These volumes are arranged WITH re-
markahle eXactness OF method, copied with
elegance and care. and written Throughout
in uniform and neat style OF penmahshiP,
Each class Of subjects is brought together
in strict Chronological order, and copion,
index is added 10 every volume.


From the time that Washington resigned
the command of the army to his acceptance
Of the Presidency, his correspondence fills 9
folio vuune,--scarcely one Of these letters
have been published.


lis letters to Nfr. Jay, upon the subject Of
the Treaty with England, are OF the highest
interest; in reference to which papers, MIR.
Sparks observtS:--"l take it upon me r.
say, without qualification, that among the
mass Of Washington's private and coutiden-
tial papers, pertaining to the stormy sea
sons of his administration, there is no rec
ord that breads the light, none that would
in the smallest degree, detract from the
brightness of his character by being expos
cd"


A most surprising and dreadful occurrence
lately took place in one Of the provinces D
France. A counterfeiter, who had beer
condemned to be hung, made his escape o,
the way to the gallows, and took refuge il
an hospital. After some search lie wa
found, as was thought, disguised. lie wa
Carried OF, uttcrlng not syllable, but ges
ticulating vehemently, and executed. 1t wa
shortly afterwards discovered that the off
GERS had hung deaf and dumb brother o
the convict who had resided long in the hos
pital. The real criminal vas recommends,
to the royal clemency.


Il Laughablc adrcntute-No long since
reverend clergyman in Vermont, being ap
prchonsive that the accumulated weight {
snow upon the roof Of his barn might d
some damage, resolved to prevent it bv sea
sonably slioyeling it off, He therefore as
oenued II, having first, for tear the sno,
might all slide otf at once, and himself wit
II, fastened to his waist one end of a rope
ana giving the other to his WIFE He wen
10 work, but fearing still tor his safety, IN
dear said he, ''tie the rope round you
waist" no sooner had she done this, than o
went the snow, poor minister and all, ant
up went his wife. Thus on one side of til
barn the astounded and confaunlcd clergy
man hung, but on the other side hung hi
vlte, high aud dry, i'll majesty sublime
dlngllng and dangling at the end of the rop,
~ that moment, however, gentleman
luckily passing by, delivered them from thei
perllous situation Per. Pat.


MI Carter of the New York Statesman
proposes to collect, revise and publish i
Wofolumes, such parts of his Letters iron
Europe, as he thinks worthy of preserva
,lon About one third of the proposed worl
sas never been given to the pubic in an

About twelve thousand children are in
structed in the Sabbath Schools in Philadel-

Mr. Zeumer, an industrious confectioner
OF Cincinnati, Ohio, was indisposed few
days last week; on Friday morning, beng
much better, he went to his shop at an early
hour, and drank freely from his cold soda
fountain. The immediate consequence was,
the rupture of a blood vessel, which caused
his death in few hours.
